abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Development Adjustment Credit Project for Guyana were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, International
            Development Association (IDA) performance during
            identification and preparation was highly satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: in the fiscal reform area, the implementation of
            tax reductions and minimum corporate taxes needs to more
            carefully take into account the effects on fiscal revenues,
            and the tax base, particularly for debt-ridden countries.
            The corporate tax reduction under the project, while meant
            to spur development and investment by the private sector,
            could only be implemented as long as the economy was growing
            at a rapid pace, and the government's fiscal position
            was improving. Following an International Monetary Fund
            (IMF) recommendation mid-way through the project, that the
            country's fiscal situation necessitated an additional
            revenue effort, the continued reduction in corporate taxes
            was halted in order to maintain the fiscal accounts in
            check. On the private sector side, the implementation of the
            minimum tax had to be waived, given that many manufacturing
            companies, who were operating on credit, did not have the
            cash flow to pay any tax at all. Thus, in future operations
            which target fiscal incentives for improving private
            investment, these reforms should be linked to underlying
            economic conditions with appropriate benchmark indicators.
            This will allow for realistic adjustments in policy targets
            of this type, these can be indexed to revenue ratios,
            especially when they are largely impacted by exogenous
            economic factors.
